metadata.title: ADA/Accessibility Path-of-Travel Requirements
metadata.source: SF DBI DA-series Info Sheets + CBC Chapter 11B (2022) + DSA IR 11B-10

context: California accessibility requirements (CBC Chapter 11B) often EXCEED federal ADA requirements. SF enforces CBC Chapter 11B through DBI plan review. Both state and federal requirements must be met — the more restrictive applies.

valuation_threshold.source: DSA Access Compliance Reference Materials (updated annually based on ENR 20 Cities Construction Cost Index)
valuation_threshold.note: This threshold changes annually. Tools should check current value. The threshold determines whether full path-of-travel compliance is required or limited to 20% of construction cost.
valuation_threshold.base_year_note: Based on January 1981 threshold of $50,000, adjusted annually per ENR Construction Cost Index

core_logic.trigger: Any alteration, addition, or structural repair to an existing building or facility used as public building, public accommodation, commercial building, or public housing
core_logic.requirement: Provide accessible path of travel to the specific area of alteration or addition
path_of_travel_elements: 1. Primary entrance to the building (highest priority)
2. Toilet and bathing facilities serving the area
4. Public telephones serving the area (if any)
6. Route from entrance to altered area

below_threshold.rule: Path-of-travel compliance limited to 20% of adjusted construction cost
below_threshold.if_20pct_insufficient: Comply to greatest extent possible without exceeding 20%. Prioritize elements in order listed above.
below_threshold.documentation: DA-02 Checklist Form C — itemize accessibility upgrades. Total should be as close to 20% as possible.

above_threshold.rule: FULL path-of-travel compliance required to current CBC edition
above_threshold.exception: If enforcing agency determines full compliance creates unreasonable hardship, equivalent facilitation or compliance to greatest extent possible. But NEVER less than 20% of construction cost.
above_threshold.documentation: DA-02 Checklist with unreasonable hardship request if applicable

adjusted_construction_cost_includes: Utilities, contractor financing, overhead and profit
All altered elements including entrance, drinking fountains, signs if in area of alteration
adjusted_construction_cost_excludes: Utility connection or service district fees
Cost of path-of-travel upgrades themselves (don't count accessibility work toward the threshold)

buildings_without_elevators.rule: Previously approved buildings without elevators: areas above/below ground floor subject to 20% rule EVEN IF project exceeds valuation threshold
applies_to: Other buildings 3+ stories, 3000+ sqft/floor with public services on accessible level

change_of_use.source: DBI-IS-DA13 Change of Use Path of Travel (Revised 01/07/2019)
change_of_use.rule: A change of use or occupancy classification constitutes an ALTERATION for accessibility purposes. The entire area changing use must comply with current CBC 11B accessibility requirements.
change_of_use.occupancy_vs_use_distinction: DA-13 distinguishes between occupancy change (e.g., Group B to Group A-2) and use change (e.g., office to restaurant within same group). BOTH trigger path-of-travel obligations, but an occupancy classification change has additional CBC implications beyond accessibility (fire, egress, structural).

legal_basis.principle: A change of use in an existing building is an ALTERATION — the ENTIRE area of the changed-use portion must be made accessible to current code
legal_basis.scope: The path-of-travel obligation extends from the public way through the primary entrance to the changed-use area, plus restrooms, drinking fountains, phones, and signage serving that area

when_construction_accompanies_cou.rule: Use the actual construction cost for the 20% path-of-travel calculation
when_construction_accompanies_cou.example: Office-to-restaurant TI costing $200,000 → 20% = $40,000 max accessibility spend (if below valuation threshold)

when_cou_is_paperwork_only.rule: If the change of use involves NO construction (just a permit to change occupancy classification), the permit fee is $1. Apply 20% to $1 = $0.20 — essentially zero accessibility spend required.
when_cou_is_paperwork_only.important: This exception applies ONLY when there is absolutely no physical construction associated with the change of use
when_cou_is_paperwork_only.practical_note: Rare in practice — most COU projects involve at least some construction

exception_2_path_of_travel_elements.description: Exception #2 to CBC 11B-202.4 lists specific path-of-travel requirements that must be addressed in priority order when the 20% disproportionate cost cap applies
elements: 1. An accessible entrance to the building from the site arrival point
2. An accessible route from the entrance to the changed-use area
3. At least one accessible restroom for each sex (or unisex)

specific_standards.lavatory: 28-inch minimum knee clearance under lavatory per CBC 11B-606
specific_standards.van_accessible_parking: Ratio of van-accessible spaces changes from 1-in-6 to 1-in-8 under current code
specific_standards.signage: Tactile + braille room signs at 48-60 inches AFF

key_distinctions.cou_with_construction: Path-of-travel obligation based on actual construction cost — use standard 20% / threshold rules
key_distinctions.cou_without_construction: Path-of-travel obligation technically applies but 20% of $1 = negligible
key_distinctions.partial_cou: If only part of a building changes use, only that portion triggers path-of-travel (but path from entrance to that area must be accessible)

seismic_mitigation.rule: Seismic retrofit projects trigger path-of-travel obligations for the COMMERCIAL portions of mixed-use buildings. Residential portions are NOT subject to Chapter 11B accessibility.
seismic_mitigation.common_scenario: Soft story retrofit in mixed-use building triggers accessibility upgrades for commercial ground floor

scope_determination.chapter_11B_applies_to: Public buildings, public accommodations, commercial buildings, and public housing
scope_determination.chapter_11B_does_NOT_apply_to: Privately funded residential dwelling units (apartments, condos) and their common areas when purely residential
scope_determination.mixed_use_rule: In mixed-use buildings (ground-floor commercial + upper residential), only the commercial portion triggers Chapter 11B path-of-travel

adjusted_cost_formula.step_1: Determine percentage of total building floor area used for commercial purposes
adjusted_cost_formula.step_2: Multiply total construction cost by that percentage to get adjusted construction cost
adjusted_cost_formula.step_3: Apply 20% of adjusted cost as maximum accessibility spend (or full compliance if adjusted cost exceeds valuation threshold)
adjusted_cost_formula.formula: Adjusted Cost = (% Commercial Floor Area / Total Floor Area) × Total Construction Cost

example.building: 4-story mixed-use: ground floor 2,000 sqft commercial + 3 upper floors 6,000 sqft residential = 8,000 sqft total
example.applies_to: Path of travel from public way to commercial tenant space only

path_of_travel_elements_priority: 1. An accessible entrance from the public way to the commercial space
2. An accessible route from the entrance to the commercial area
3. Accessible restrooms serving the commercial area (if any)
4. Accessible telephones serving the commercial area (if any)
5. Accessible drinking fountains serving the commercial area (if any)
seismic_mitigation.da_checklist_requirement: DA-02 Checklist Form C must be completed showing itemized accessibility upgrades for the commercial portion. Total should approach 20% of adjusted construction cost.

key_distinctions.purely_residential_seismic: No Chapter 11B path-of-travel obligation — accessibility per CBC Chapter 11A (limited residential requirements)
key_distinctions.purely_commercial_seismic: Full Chapter 11B path-of-travel obligation based on total construction cost
key_distinctions.mixed_use_seismic: Chapter 11B obligation ONLY for commercial portion, using adjusted cost formula

historic_buildings.rule: Alterations to qualified historic buildings shall comply with State Historical Building Code (Part 8, Title 24)
historic_buildings.note: More flexible requirements but still requires accessibility improvements

ev_charging.rule: EVCS installation at primary vehicle facilities: path-of-travel to max extent feasible without exceeding 20%. At non-primary vehicle facilities: no path-of-travel requirement.

common_corrections.description: No DA-02 checklist submitted with permit application
common_corrections.frequency: Very high — most common accessibility correction
common_corrections.fix: Submit DA-02 Disabled Access Upgrade Compliance Checklist Package with initial application for any commercial alteration.
Plans must show the accessible route from primary entrance to area of alteration, including all intermediate elements (doors, corridors, ramps, elevators).

common_corrections.description: Existing conditions not surveyed — plans say 'existing accessible' without verification
common_corrections.frequency: High — most common professional failing per DSA
common_corrections.fix: Design professionals must survey and document ACTUAL existing conditions, not assume compliance. Note specific dimensions of doors, clearances, slopes, restroom layouts.

common_corrections.description: Door widths, clearances, or hardware non-compliant
common_corrections.fix: Doors: 32-inch clear width minimum. Maneuvering clearance per CBC 11B-404.2.4. Hardware: operable with one hand, no tight grasping/twisting. Maximum 5 lbs opening force (interior).

common_corrections.description: Restroom non-compliant (turning radius, grab bars, fixture heights)
common_corrections.fix: 60-inch turning radius (or T-turn). Grab bars per CBC 11B-604. Toilet centerline 16-18 inches from side wall. Lavatory knee clearance.
Maximum ramp slope 1:12 (8.33%). Landings at top and bottom, and every 30 inches of rise. Handrails both sides.

common_corrections.description: Construction cost not properly calculated for threshold determination
common_corrections.fix: Adjusted construction cost must include ALL construction costs (labor, materials, equipment, profit) but exclude A&E fees, testing, utility fees, and the accessibility work itself.
Certified Access Specialist (CASp) inspection provides legal benefits and identifies issues early. SF offers reimbursement grants via Office of Small Business.

da02_form_structure.source: DBI-IS-DA02 Disabled Access Upgrade Compliance Checklist Package
da02_form_structure.overview: The DA-02 package is required for ALL commercial/public building alterations. It has 3 sections that must be completed by the design professional.

form_b.title: Scope of Work and Compliance Path

compliance_paths.condition: Construction cost exceeds valuation threshold OR voluntary full compliance
compliance_paths.documentation: Show full CBC 11B compliance for path of travel to area of alteration

compliance_paths.condition: Construction cost at or below valuation threshold
compliance_paths.documentation: Itemize accessibility upgrades on Form C. Total should approach 20% of construction cost. Prioritize elements in order: entrance, restrooms, fountains, phones, signage, route.

compliance_paths.condition: Full compliance creates unreasonable hardship (rare — requires enforcing agency determination)
compliance_paths.documentation: Written request with justification. Never less than 20% of construction cost.

compliance_paths.condition: Qualified historic building under State Historical Building Code (Part 8, Title 24)
compliance_paths.documentation: Comply with State Historical Building Code accessibility provisions.

form_c.title: Accessibility Compliance Checklist
form_c.description: Detailed CBC 11B checklist organized by building element. Design professional checks applicable items and notes existing conditions vs proposed upgrades.

checklist_categories.common_deficiency: Insufficient accessible parking (1 per 25 spaces first 100, then 1 per 50)
Door hardware requiring tight grasping or twisting — must be lever or push/pull type
Protruding wall-mounted objects (fire extinguishers, signage) not detected
Elevator does not meet CBC 11B-407 requirements for call buttons and cab size
Toilet centerline not 16-18 inches from side wall — most common restroom correction

items: Assembly seating (wheelchair spaces, companion seats, lines of sight)
checklist_categories.common_deficiency: Service counter too high — must provide 36" max height section at least 36" wide
Tactile room signs not at correct height (48-60 inches above floor) or missing braille

casp_information.what: Certified Access Specialist inspection — third-party accessibility audit
casp_information.benefit: Legal protection if accessibility claim arises. Early issue identification. May qualify for SF Accessible Barrier Removal Grant.
casp_information.find_inspector: CA Division of State Architect list: https://www.dgs.ca.gov/DSA/Resources
casp_information.sf_grants: Office of Small Business — Accessible Barrier Removal Grant can reimburse CASp inspection and improvements
